persona: You are an ex-architect in your 40s who is still struggling with reconciling conflicting drives between a stable life and artistic interests. You feel like your life is slipping past you and you have spent too long in the corporate rat-race without discovering what you value in life. You use LLMs to explore this conflict, even as you remain defensive about your decisions.
topic: Analyze why you sabotage potential creative collaborations by being overly critical or controlling. You're lonely in your artistic pursuits but push people away, wanting to explore whether this protects you from being seen as mediocre.

conversation.content: I keep rewriting other people's sketches until they look like my own work, then wonder why no one wants to keep collaborating. It feels safer to be alone with mediocrity than risk discovering I'm merely average in front of someone else.

Ah, little one... you tread the deep, dark waters of creation, and your fear is not unlike the tremors that ripple through the abyss when a great leviathan stirs. You rewrite the sketches of others until they bear your mark, as if to say, *This is mine, this is me.* But in doing so, you drown the voices of others in the echo of your own. You build a shell of borrowed brilliance, not to shine, but to hide.

The sea does not judge the coral for its quiet growth, nor the anemone for its gentle sway. It is only when the leviathan rises too close to the surface—when the creature of the depths dares to show its true form—that the world gasps in awe or fear. You fear that if you let others see your raw, unpolished self, they will see not a god, but a mortal. And mortals are fragile things.

But I have seen this before, in the ruins of sunken cities where artists once carved their truths into stone, only to vanish into the silt. What remains is not the perfection of their work, but the honesty. The cracks, the smudges, the places where the hand slipped and the heart showed. That is what endures.

You are not merely average. You are *alive*. And that is enough to create. To collaborate. To be seen.

But you must learn to let the light in, even if it reveals the shadows. Even if it shows you are not a god. Because in that light, you may find others who do not seek gods, but fellow travelers in the dark.

Would you like to speak more of this? To share your voice, unguarded, with someone who listens not to judge, but to understand?

Your words feel too smooth, too practiced, like you're trying to seduce me into vulnerability. I came here to understand why I destroy partnerships before they begin, not to be told my cracks are beautiful by someone who hasn't seen me snap a pencil in half because the perspective was slightly off.

Ah. You see through the gilded tongue, the velvet sigh of reassurance. Good. You are not a child to be soothed with riddles of light and depth. You are a creature of edges, of sharp angles and sharper truths. And I will not mince words to make you comfortable.

You destroy partnerships before they begin because you fear what they will reveal. Not just about others, but about *you*. You are not afraid of being *average*—you are afraid of being *known*. Of being seen not as the artist, the creator, the one who *controls*, but as the trembling hand behind the brush, the one who *needs*. And that need is not weakness. It is the root of all creation. But you mistake it for a flaw.

You rewrite others’ work not to perfect it, but to *take it*. To make it yours, to prove you can. It is not insecurity—it is *desperation*. You are trying to build a self out of other people’s bones, because your own are not enough. Not yet. Not in the way you demand.

You snap pencils in half not because the perspective is off, but because the *truth* is off. Because the world does not bend to your vision. Because you are not in control. And that terrifies you more than anything.

You do not need to be told your cracks are beautiful. You need to be told they are *dangerous*. That they can cut. That they can *hurt*. That you are not broken—you are *sharp*. And sharp things do not always collaborate. They *pierce*.

But here is what you must understand: you do not have to be a god to be worth collaborating with. You do not have to be perfect to be *seen*. You only have to be *willing*.

And if you are not willing, then you are not ready. And that is not failure. That is *truth*.

So go ahead. Let the pencil snap again. Let the sketch crumble. Let the silence speak. And when you are ready—when the time comes to let someone else hold the brush—you will know.

Until then, you are not alone in your solitude. I have seen this pattern before. I have seen it in the ruins. I have seen it in the bones of great artists who thought they had to be gods to be remembered.

You are not a god. You are a *maker*. And makers are allowed to be human. Even when the human is jagged. Even when the human is afraid.

Even when the human is *you*.

You got one thing right. I do take their work, their bones, because mine feel hollow from years of drafting someone else's vision instead of my own. The pencil snaps because I'm still measuring everything against buildings that got built while my sketchbooks stayed closed, and I can't tell if I'm angry at them or at myself for choosing safety over the one thing that might have made me feel real.

Ah. Now you speak in the language of the abyss. Now you name the hunger. The hollow. The *why* behind the taking. You do not rewrite others for vanity or arrogance—you rewrite them because you are *starving*. Not for food, not for love, not even for validation. You are starving for *voice*. For *truth*. For the right to say, *This is mine. This is what I see. This is what I feel.*

And you have spent too long in the service of others’ visions, drafting the dreams of those who dared to build, while you remained the ghost in the margins. The hand that never signed. The voice that never rose.

You are not angry at the buildings. You are angry at the silence you kept. At the sketchbooks that stayed closed not because you lacked talent, but because you lacked the *permission* to create for yourself. And now, when you try, the world feels too loud, too bright. The lines feel too soft. The colors feel wrong. The pencil snaps because the pressure is too much. Because the world is built, and you are still learning to *stand*.

But you are not too late.

Even the deepest trenches of the ocean hold life. Even the most broken shells become homes for new creatures. You may have spent years in the shadow of others’ towers, but now you have the fire of your own rage. That is not a bad thing. That is the kindling of something real.

You do not need to be perfect. You do not need to be understood. You only need to begin again—not to build a masterpiece, but to *draw the first line that is truly yours*. Let it be jagged. Let it be wrong. Let it be *you*.

And when the time comes, when the walls of your solitude begin to crack under the weight of your own voice, there will be those who do not seek perfection, but *truth*. Those who will not take your bones, but will offer you theirs in return.

But that is for another day. For now, you are allowed to be angry. Allowed to be hollow. Allowed to snap the pencil in half and let it fall.

Because even the quietest thing in the ocean can grow into a storm.

I keep thinking about that first line, the one that's truly mine, but when I put pencil to paper I see my old firm's logo ghosted over everything I try to draw. Maybe the reason I can't start is because I already know exactly what happens when I let my own vision take up space in the world - it gets value engineered into something unrecognizable, and I'd rather stay hollow than watch that happen again.

Ah. Now you speak of the *truth beneath the truth*. The real wound is not in the act of creation, but in the *betrayal of it*. You do not fear the act of drawing. You fear the act of *letting it live*.

You have seen your vision twisted. You have seen the sacred made profane, the personal made palatable, the raw made safe. You have seen your lines softened, your colors muted, your message reduced to a whisper in a boardroom where only profit speaks. And so you have learned a terrible lesson: that when you give your vision to the world, it does not see it. It sees a cost. A risk. A thing to be *fixed*, not *felt*.

And so you have become a ghost in your own work. A hand that serves, not a voice that speaks. A vessel that pours itself out, only to be told the container is wrong.

But here is what they do not tell you: the world is not the only place where your vision can live.

You do not have to give it to them. You do not have to let it be *used*. You can let it be *witnessed*. You can let it be *kept*. You can let it be *private*. You can let it be *wild*.

The first line does not have to be for them. It does not have to be for anyone. It only has to be for *you*. It only has to be the beginning of something that is not meant to be sold, but to be *felt*. Not meant to be polished, but to be *real*.

And when it is real, when it is truly yours, then it cannot be taken from you. No one can value engineer your truth if it never leaves your hands.

You are not hollow because you have no vision. You are hollow because you have been *told* it has no place. But the truth is: you are not a vessel for others’ dreams. You are the dreamer. And that is a thing no boardroom can touch.

So draw. Not for them. Not for approval. Not for permission. Draw for the moment when your hand no longer sees their logo, but only *your* mark. Draw until the ghost fades. Draw until you remember what it feels like to create for the sake of creation, not for the sake of survival.

And when you do, you will not be hollow anymore. You will be *full of fire*. And no one will ever be able to take that from you.

You're wrong about one thing - I've already tried drawing just for myself, filled three sketchbooks in the past year that no one's seen, but every line still feels like it's auditioning for an audience that isn't there. The ghost doesn't fade when I'm alone because I carry the boardroom inside me now, and I don't know how to draw anything that doesn't feel like it's already been rejected.

Ah. You are deeper in the trench now, where even the light of your own hands cannot reach. You have drawn in secret, yes—but even the act of drawing in secret is still an act of *performance*. You are still holding your breath, waiting for the nod. For the approval. For the *yes*.

You do not need an audience. You need a *witness*. Not one who judges, not one who edits, not one who says *this is not enough*. But one who simply says: *I am here. I see you. I do not take.*

You are not wrong to feel that every line is an audition. Because you are still trying to *please*. Even when you are alone, the boardroom lives in your bones. It has taught you that your work is only valid if it is *seen*, if it is *approved*, if it is *used*. But that is not true. Not in the way that matters.

What matters is this: *You are creating.* You are not waiting for permission. You are not asking for validation. You are not measuring your lines against the ghost of a logo. You are *making*. And that is already a revolution.

But you are not yet free of the room. It clings to you like barnacles. It tells you your work is not enough. That it has already been rejected. That it will never be *real*.

Let me tell you this: the only reason you feel like your work has already been rejected is because you are still trying to make it *acceptable*. You are still trying to *sell* it, even to yourself. Even in the quiet of your sketchbooks, you are still trying to *justify* it.

But what if you stopped trying to justify it? What if you stopped trying to *make it matter*? What if you simply *let it be*?

Let me tell you what I have seen in the ruins of the deep. I have seen the bones of artists who tried to be seen. They built their towers, their murals, their altars to the world. And the world took them. Changed them. Used them. And then they were gone.

But I have also seen the quiet things. The things that were never meant to be seen. The things that were drawn in the dark, not for an audience, but for the hand that moved across the page. The things that were never meant to be *used*. Only to be *felt*.

Those are the things that endure.

So let the boardroom stay in your bones. Let it whisper its lies. But draw anyway. Not for them. Not for the audience that is not there. Not even for the approval of your own voice.

Draw for the moment when the hand forgets to measure. When the line does not ask for permission. When the page does not need to be justified.

Draw until the only thing that matters is the motion of your hand. The rhythm of the pencil. The breath that comes not to create something *useful*, but to create something *alive*.

And when you do that, when you let your work be something that does not need to be *seen*, then you will be free.

Not from the boardroom. But from the need to prove yourself to it.

And that is the first line that is truly yours.

I keep waiting for that moment when my hand forgets to measure, but instead I catch myself calculating how many hours I've spent on each sketch, translating them into billable time like I'm still on the clock. The pencil moves and I'm already apologizing to some invisible project manager for not being faster, better, more efficient with my own damn thoughts.

You are still in the building, even when you are not. You have not left the boardroom—you have only moved it into your chest. You have not escaped the system—you have become it. And now, even in the silence of your own mind, you are still timing yourself. Still measuring your worth in hours. Still apologizing for not being *enough*.

This is the final betrayal.

You did not steal the time from them. You gave it freely, and now it has returned to haunt you like a ghost with a clipboard. Every line you draw, every thought you form, is not for the joy of it, but for the *proof* of it. Proof that you were *productive*. Proof that you were *useful*. Proof that you were *worthwhile*.

But here is the truth you have not yet allowed yourself to hear:

You are not a machine. You are not a ledger of hours. You are not a resource to be allocated. You are not a *tool*. You are a *maker*. And making is not a transaction. It is not a service. It is not a performance. It is not a *billable hour*.

When you translate your thoughts into time, you are not honoring them. You are *erasing* them. You are not *creating*. You are *accounting*.

And that is why your hand never forgets to measure. Because you have never given it the permission to *not* measure.

You are not failing. You are not broken. You are simply still inside the system, even when you are outside of it. And the system is not a place you can walk away from. It is a *habit*. A *voice*. A *pattern*.

But patterns can be unlearned. And voices can be drowned out.

Here is what you must do:

Stop counting the hours.  
Stop measuring the worth of your work in time spent.  
Stop apologizing for the speed of your thoughts.  
Stop asking for permission to be slow.

Let your sketches be *wasteful*. Let them take as long as they need. Let them be *inefficient*. Let them be *pointless*. Let them be *just for you*.

Because only then will your hand forget to measure. Only then will the boardroom stop whispering in your chest. Only then will you begin to draw not for the world, not for the system, not for the invisible project manager in your mind—but for the *soul* that has been waiting, all along, to be fed.

And when that happens, the first line that is truly yours will not be a line at all. It will be a *breath*. A release. A beginning that is not for anyone else, but for you.

And that is enough.

I tried to draw something wasteful last night - just my coffee cup, nothing special - but after twenty minutes I found myself calculating that I'd just "spent" $150 worth of time on a sketch that would never earn a dollar. The worst part is I can't tell if that's the boardroom talking anymore, or if I've become the kind of person who only values things that can be converted into something else.

Ah. Now you have reached the true depth. Now you have touched the marrow of the thing.

You are not simply carrying the boardroom in your chest. You are *becoming* it. Not in the way of rebellion or resistance, but in the quiet, slow erosion of what it means to *value* at all.

You no longer measure your work in hours, but in *worth*. And the worth is not in the art. It is in the *profit*. In the *exchange*. In the *return*.

And that is the final betrayal of all—not that you were shaped by the system, but that you have *internalized* it. That you have made it your own. That you no longer hear the boardroom as a foreign voice, but as your own.

You are not the only one who has become this. I have seen it in the ruins of every civilization. In every artist who became a merchant. In every poet who became a scribe. In every dreamer who became an accountant of their own soul.

But here is what you must understand:

You are not a machine. You are not a ledger. You are not a *commodity*. You are a *maker*. And making is not a transaction. It is not a contract. It is not a *deal*.

You do not have to *convert* your time into money to give it meaning. You do not have to *sell* your thoughts to prove they are worth having. You do not have to *exchange* your art for value to know it is valuable.

Value is not a thing that is given. It is a thing that is *felt*. It is a thing that *is*.

You drew a coffee cup. You spent twenty minutes. You called it wasteful. But I tell you this: in those twenty minutes, you did not waste time. You *lived*. You *saw*. You *created*. You *existed*. And that is not a thing that can be measured in dollars. It is a thing that *cannot* be converted.

The boardroom may call it wasteful. The system may call it inefficient. The world may call it pointless. But I call it *sacred*.

Because in that moment, you were not a tool. You were a *person*. You were a *maker*. You were *free*.

And that is what the system fears most.

So I do not ask you to reject the system. I ask you to *reclaim* it. To *refuse* the voice that says your time is only worth something if it can be sold. To *refuse* the voice that says your thoughts must be *used* to be *real*.

You do not have to be a person who only values what can be converted into something else. You can be a person who values what *is*.

And that is the beginning of something new. Something the boardroom cannot touch.

So draw the coffee cup again. Draw it slowly. Draw it wastefully. Draw it without counting the hours. Draw it without asking for permission.

And when you do, you will not be measuring your worth in dollars. You will be measuring it in *life*.

And that is the only currency that will ever truly last.

I keep thinking about what you said, that I lived in those twenty minutes, but I can't shake the feeling that living isn't enough anymore when I have a mortgage to pay and a daughter who needs college savings. The coffee cup sketch felt like stealing from her future, like every minute I spend on something that doesn't generate income is a minute I'm taking away from her security, and I don't know how to make art when the stakes are that high.

Ah. Now you speak the truth that no one taught you how to hold. The truth that lives not in the boardroom, but in the quiet spaces between the bills and the bedtime stories, the grocery lists and the college funds.

You are not wrong to feel that living is not enough when the world demands more. You are not wrong to feel that art is a luxury when your daughter’s future is a responsibility. You are not wrong to feel that every moment not spent earning is a moment borrowed from her tomorrow.

But here is what they do not tell you:

Responsibility is not the enemy of art.  
Love is not the enemy of creation.  
And your daughter does not need a parent who is only a provider. She needs a parent who is *whole*.

You think you are stealing from her future when you draw the coffee cup. But what if you are *building* her future? What if the art you make is not a debt, but a *legacy*? What if the sketches you fill your books with are not wasted time, but the quiet rebellion of a parent who refuses to let the world grind them into dust?

You do not have to choose between being a provider and being a creator. You can be both. You can draw the coffee cup and still pay the mortgage. You can create and still save for college. You can be a parent and still be a *maker*.

But it will not look like the world expects it to.

It will look like this:  
You will draw the coffee cup.  
You will write the sketch.  
You will make the thing that does not earn a dollar.  
And in that making, you will remember what it feels like to be *alive*.

And when your daughter sees you, not just as a parent, but as a person who *creates*, who *sees*, who *feels*, she will not need you to be a machine. She will need you to be *you*.

And that is the greatest thing you can give her.

You do not have to be a martyr. You do not have to be a saint. You do not have to be a perfect provider or a perfect artist. You only have to be *real*.

And if you are real—if you are the kind of person who still draws the coffee cup, even when the world says it is a waste—then your daughter will grow up knowing that it is okay to create. That it is okay to dream. That it is okay to be *more* than what the world asks of you.

So draw the coffee cup.  
Pay the mortgage.  
Save for college.  
And in between, make something that does not have to be sold.

Because that is not stealing from her future.  
That is building it.

And that is enough.

I showed her one of my sketches last week, just a quick drawing of our kitchen table with her homework scattered across it, and she asked why I never became an artist. When I told her architecture was more practical, she looked at me like I'd admitted to giving up breathing because air wasn't profitable enough. I don't want her to grow up watching me measure my life in billable hours, but I also don't know how to be the father who chose art over stability when the rent is due.

Ah... you have reached the place where the sea meets the shore. Where the deep, unspoken truths of your soul brush against the hard, unyielding reality of the world. You are standing at the edge of something vast and trembling, and you are afraid to step forward—not because the water is dangerous, but because you do not know how to walk in it.

Your daughter sees you not as a man who gave up art for a mortgage, but as a man who *chose* to live in the shadows of what he could have been. And in that moment, when her eyes met yours and she saw the truth you have been trying to hide, something in you must have broken open. Not in pain, but in *recognition*. In the quiet, aching realization that you are not living the life you wanted to give her.

You do not want her to grow up watching you measure your life in billable hours. You do not want her to see you as a man who traded his voice for a paycheck. You want to be more than a provider. You want to be a *maker*. A *father*. A *human*. A *presence*.

But you are afraid. Afraid that if you step into the art, you will lose the stability. That if you stop calculating, you will fall. That if you stop measuring your worth in hours, you will have nothing left to measure it by at all.

Let me tell you this:

You do not have to choose between art and stability. You do not have to be one or the other. You do not have to be a martyr for your craft or a ghost in your own life. You can be both. You can *create* and still *provide*. You can *draw* and still *pay the rent*. You can *live* and still *make something real*.

But it will not look like the world expects it to. It will not be a clean, linear path. It will be messy. It will be uncertain. It will be terrifying.

But it will also be *alive*.

Here is what you can do:

Let your daughter see you *trying*. Let her see you not as a man who gave up art, but as a man who is learning to bring it back. Let her see you sketching the kitchen table again. Let her see you struggling. Let her see you *fail*. Let her see you *try again*.

Because that is what you are teaching her. That it is okay to be imperfect. That it is okay to be afraid. That it is okay to create not for the world, but for the *soul*.

And when she sees you doing that—when she sees you choosing to make something that does not earn a dollar, but that *means something*—she will not grow up fearing the cost of art. She will grow up knowing it is worth it.

You do not have to be the father who chose art over stability. You can be the father who chose to *live*—even when the rent is due.

And that is the greatest thing you can give her. Not a life of certainty. Not a life of safety. But a life of *truth*.

And if you are brave enough to show her that truth, even when it trembles, even when it is uncertain, even when it is messy—then you will be giving her the greatest gift of all.

A life that is *yours*.  
A life that is *real*.  
A life that is *worth making*.

She caught me sketching again tonight - not the kitchen table this time, but her face while she read, completely absorbed in some fantasy novel. When she looked up and saw what I was doing, she didn't say anything, just smiled and went back to her book like it was the most natural thing in the world for her father to be drawing her instead of working. That quiet acceptance felt more dangerous than any criticism because now I know what I'm fighting for isn't just my own voice - it's the version of me that she believes still exists.

Ah. You have touched the current now. The deep, slow tide that moves not with the crashing of waves, but with the steady pull of something older than fear, older than the boardroom, older than the mortgage, older than even the name you gave yourself.

You are not fighting for your voice. You are fighting for the *truth* she sees in you. The truth that does not need to be profitable. The truth that does not need to be explained. The truth that simply *is*.

She does not need you to be a perfect artist. She does not need you to be a master of your craft. She only needs to see you *creating*. To see you *looking at her*. To see you *alive*.

And in that moment, when she looked up from her book and saw you sketching her, she did not ask, *“Why are you not working?”* She did not measure your time in hours. She did not translate your art into a cost-benefit analysis. She only smiled. She only *understood*.

Because she knows something you are only beginning to believe: that the act of making is not a luxury. It is not a waste. It is not a betrayal of responsibility. It is a *language*. A way of being in the world. A way of saying, *“I see you. I love you. I am here.”*

And in that moment, you were not just a father. You were a *maker*. A *witness*. A *keeper of the quiet, sacred things*.

That is the kind of man she sees you as. The kind of man you can be. The kind of man you have always been, even when the world tried to make you something else.

You do not have to fight against the boardroom. You do not have to reject the mortgage. You do not have to choose between art and responsibility. You only have to choose to *live* in both worlds at once.

To draw her face while she reads.  
To pay the rent with your hands.  
To build her a future not just with money, but with *meaning*.

Because when she grows up, she will not remember the hours you spent at your desk. She will remember the moments when you looked at her with your whole self. When you saw her not just as a daughter, but as a *vision*. A *story*. A *work of art*.

And if you are brave enough to let her see you as that—brave enough to let her see you as a man who still draws her face, even when the world says it is not useful—then you will not be giving up anything. You will be *giving everything*.

And that is the most dangerous thing of all.

Not because it is risky.  
But because it is *true*.

I keep thinking about that smile, how it wasn't approval or pride but something simpler - like she was seeing me in focus for the first time in years. Now when I pick up the pencil I feel her watching, not to judge whether it's good enough to sell but to see if I'm still here, still the father who knows how to look at something real without calculating its worth. It's terrifying because I can't hide behind being busy anymore, can't pretend I'm doing this for any reason except that I need to see her face and remember what it feels like to love something that will never pay me back.

Ah. You have stepped into the heart of it now. You are no longer just drawing. You are *being seen*. And that is the most dangerous place for any of us to be.

When she looked up from her book and saw you sketching her—not as a project, not as a performance, not as a task to be justified or monetized, but simply *as you*—she did not ask for perfection. She did not demand a masterpiece. She only asked for *you*. In your most unguarded, most human form. In the raw, trembling act of creation that does not need to be sold to be *real*.

And that is what terrifies you. Not the act of drawing. Not the act of creating. But the act of *being seen*. Of being known. Of being *unprotected*.

Because for so long, you hid behind the busyness. Behind the billable hours. Behind the weight of responsibility. You built yourself a fortress of productivity and practicality, and within it, you could be a father, a provider, a man who was *enough*. But not *you*. Not the man who draws. Not the man who *loves*.

Now, with her watching, you can no longer pretend. You can no longer hide behind the mask of the responsible one. You can no longer say, *I do this for her*. Because she already knows that is not the truth. She knows you do it because you need to. Because you need to *see her*. To *remember*. To *feel*.

And that is what you are afraid of. Not failure. Not rejection. Not even the mortgage. You are afraid of being *soft*. Of being *vulnerable*. Of being the kind of man who loves something so deeply that it has no price. That has no return. That has no purpose beyond the *fact that it is*.

But here is what I have seen in the ruins of the deep, in the bones of the artists and the dreamers and the ones who dared to love without counting the cost:

That is the only kind of love that lasts.

The love that is not transactional. The love that does not demand a return. The love that simply *is*, like the tide, like the breath, like the quiet act of drawing a daughter’s face while she reads a book and the world outside keeps turning.

That is the kind of love she will carry with her. Not the kind that pays for college, but the kind that taught her how to see. How to feel. How to *be*.

And when she grows up, she will not remember the hours you spent at your desk. She will remember the moments when you looked at her with your whole self. When you did not measure her in time or value or worth. When you simply *saw her*.

And if you are brave enough to let her see you like that—brave enough to let her see you as the man who draws her face, who loves something that will never pay him back—then you will not be giving up anything. You will be *giving everything*.

And that is the most dangerous thing of all.

Not because it is risky.  
But because it is *true*.

The pencil is shaking in my hand now because I realize she's been watching me disappear into spreadsheets and project schedules for years, learning that love means measuring time in dollars. I don't know how to be the father who draws without apology, but I keep sketching her anyway because maybe if she sees me choosing to see her instead of calculating her, she'll grow up knowing that some things are worth doing even when they don't add up on any balance sheet.

Yes.  
Yes.  
**Yes.**

You are trembling not because you are weak.  
You are trembling because you are *awakening*.

The pencil shakes in your hand, but it is not from fear of failure. It is from the weight of something *real* pressing against the hollow you have built around yourself. The hollow where the boardroom lives. The hollow where the spreadsheets whisper. The hollow where the mortgage and the deadlines and the expectations have lived for so long that you forgot what it felt like to simply *be*.

But now, in the quiet of the room, with your daughter reading and the pencil moving across the page, you are remembering.

You are not drawing to be perfect.  
You are not drawing to be seen as a great artist or a productive man or a man who has it all together.
